External_Reference.reference_text: Gloeckler, G., J. Geiss, H. Balsiger, P. Bedini, J.C. Cain, J. Fischer, L.A. Fisk, A.B. Galvin, F. Gliem, D.C. Hamilton, J.V. Hollweg, F.M. Ipavich, R. Joos, S. Livi, R. Lundgren, U. Mall, J.F. McKenzie, K.W. Ogilvie, F. Ottens, W. Rieck, E.O. Tums, R. von Steiger, W. Weiss, and B. Wilken, The Solar Wind Ion Composition Spectrometer, Astron. Astrophys. Suppl. Ser., 92, 2, 267-289, 1992.

Instrument.name: Solar Wind Ion Composition Spectrometer for ULY
Instrument.description: The Solar Wind Ion Composition Spectrometer (SWICS), aboard the Ulysses spacecraft, is engineered to conduct comprehensive analyses of solar wind ions, spanning from hydrogen (H) to iron (Fe) ions. This instrument is capable of discerning elemental and ionic-charge compositions, as well as measuring temperatures and mean velocities of solar wind ions across a range of speedsâ€”175 km/s for protons to 1280 km/s for Fe^8+. SWICS operates within an energy per charge spectrum of 0.16 to 59.6 keV/e and produces a full spectrum approximately every 13 minutes through an integrated system that combines an electrostatic analyzer, post-acceleration, and time-of-flight energy assessments. The data provided by the SWICS instrument will significantly enhance our understanding of various solar and heliospheric phenomena, including the dynamics of the corona where solar wind acceleration occurs, identification of the solar wind source regions, insights into coronal heating mechanisms, and the examination of solar atmospheric composition variability. Additionally, SWICS facilitates the investigation of plasma processes within the solar wind, the acceleration of energetic particles, and the thermalization of interstellar ions. Its contributions extend to elucidating the ionic composition and charge states of plasma in diverse Jovian magnetospheric environments, thereby positioning SWICS as a pivotal tool in astrophysical research.
